citeinfo.origin: Terry L. Sohl, U.S. Geological Survey - Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center, Sioux Falls, South Dakota
citeinfo.title: DS-777 Annual Model-Forecasted Land-Use/Land-Cover Rasters from 2009 to 2050 for the B2 Climate Scenario for the High Plains Aquifer in Parts of Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, New Mexico, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Texas, and Wyoming
citeinfo.othercit: Current as of publication date. No revisions planned.

citeinfo.title: Geodatabase Compilation of Hydrogeologic, Remote Sensing, and Water-Budget-Component data for the High Plains aquifer, 2011

descript.abstract: Estimates of area and aerial extent of land use categories are an essential component for computing the water budget of the High Plains aquifer. These raster land-use/land-cover data represent yearly simulated future land-use/land-cover for the High Plains from 2009 to 2050. These data were developed using the FOREcasting SCEnarios (FORE-SCE) of future land cover model (Sohl and others, 2007; Sohl and Sayler 2008) for two (A2 and B2) of the four Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) climate scenarios and then processed using a Geographic Information System (GIS). The GIS software used to process these data was Environmental Systems Research Institute (ESRI, Inc.) ArcGIS Desktop 10.0.
descript.purpose: The purpose of these raster data are for use as input to a Soil Water Balance Model (SWB). SWB uses topography, soil properties, and land use to simulate recharge rates and groundwater withdrawals (irrigation pumpage). The simulated recharge rates were then used in a groundwater-flow model.
descript.supplinf:
This geodatabase contains 42 rasters organized by year. The naming convention for the rasters in this geodatabase is "flulc_b2_xxxx" where xxxx represents the year from 2009 to 2050 (for example flulc_b2_2020 is the predicted land-use raster for 2020).

dataqual.complete: Data set is complete for the High Plains aquifer.

procstep.procdesc: Predicted (forecasted) land-use/land-cover(LULC) data for the area overlying the High Plains aquifer from 2009-2050 was constructed using the FORE-SCE (FOREcasting SCEnarios of future land cover) model (Sohl and others, 2007; Sohl and Sayler, 2008). Future scenarios were developed using characteristics and assumptions consistent with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Special Report on Emissions Scenarios (SRES) storylines A2 and B2 (Nakicenovic and others, 2000) and historical data from the USGS Land Cover Trends project (Loveland and others, 2002). A Protected Areas Database for the United States (U.S. Geological Survey, 2010) was used to restrict LULC change on currently protected public lands. Starting LULC was based on the U.S. Department of Agriculture's 2008 Cropland Data Layer(CDL) (U.S. Department of Agriculture, 2008). The CDL was collapsed into the following 18 classes; corn, cotton, sorghum, soybeans, wheat and small grains, alfalfa/hay, other crops, fallow, open water, developed, barren, deciduous forest, mixed forest, evergreen forest, shrubland, grassland, woody wetland, herbaceous wetland, and perennial ice/snow. Probability surfaces for each LULC were developed using logistic regression to analyze relationships between LULC distributions and drivers. Individual patches of LULC change were then placed on the landscape in an iterative modeling procedures until the scenario-prescribed proportions of LULC change for a given year were met, with patch characteristics determined by historical regional trends and scenario storylines. Spatial modeling of the two scenarios provided spatial patterns of land-use change consistent with underlying assumptions and processes associated with each scenario. The economically oriented scenario (A2) was characterized by loss of natural land covers and expansion of agricultural and urban land uses. The environmentally oriented scenario (B2) experienced declines in agriculture and slight increases in natural land covers.

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey - Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center

procstep.procdesc: The data received from Terry Sohl were then "clipped" to the High Plains aquifer extent.

enttyp.enttypd: Value attribute table for the predicted land-use/land-cover raster data scenario b2

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Count of cells with the specified value

attrdomv.udom: The set of all positive real numbers.

attr.attrdef: Name of the land-use/ land-cover classification

attrdomv.udom: Random values that do not lend themselves to range typing

attr.attrdef: Value for the red component of the RGB ramp
Value for the green component of the RGB ramp
Value for the blue component of the RGB ramp
A binary field that determines the visibility

overview.eaover: The values of the raster set represent the predicted land-use /land-cover classification for the b2 scenario for the time period 2009 to 2050 for the High Plains aquifer.
overview.eadetcit: These raster data were produced for use in the northern High Plains groundwater-flow model. Data presented in this Data Series report are the raw raster data produced by EROS for the full High Plains aquifer extent.
